## Monopoly & Perfect Competition Example

No better way to learn than by doing. Let a firm have the following cost function and face the following Demand Curve

$$
    C(Q) = 2Q^{2} + 2Q \;\;\;\;\; \& \;\;\;\;\; P = 26 - 2Q_{D}
$$

We will:

::: {.incremental}
- Find the [Supply Curve]{.hi}, [Market Equilibrium Price]{.hi}, and [Quantity]{.hi} assuming the firm is a [Price Taker]{.hi}
- Find [Monopoly Price & Quantity]{.hi-red} 
- Show Profits are higher in the [Monopoly Market]{.hi-red}
- Graph the found Curves
- Add the Price, Quantities, & Profits
:::

---

## Finding Perfect Competition Equilibrium

$$
    C(Q) = 2Q^{2} + 2Q \;\;\;\;\; \& \;\;\;\;\; P = 26 - 2Q_{D}
$$

[Find the Perfectly Competitive Market Equilibrium Price and Quantity]{.hi .note .align-center}

[Hint: In Perfect Competition Supply = MC]{.hi .small .align-center}

. . .

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="30%"}
[Find the Supply Curve]{.hi .align-center}

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    P &= MC \\
    P &= 4Q_{S} + 2
\end{align*}
:::

:::

::: {.column width="70%"}
[Set Supply Equal to Demand]{.hi .align-center}
[Remember $\; Q_{S} = Q_{D} = Q$]{.hi .small .align-center}

::: {.fragment .small}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}

\begin{align*}
    \text{Supply} &= \text{Demand} \\
    4Q + 2 &= 26 - 2Q \\
    6Q &= 24 \\
    Q^{*}_{PC} &= 4
\end{align*}

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

<br>

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    P^{*}_{PC} &= 26 - 2Q^{*} \\
    P^{*}_{PC} &= 26 - 2(4) \\
    P^{*}_{PC} &= 18
\end{align*}
:::

:::

:::

::::

:::

::::

---

## Finding Monopoly Equilibrium {.smaller}

$$
    C(Q) = 2Q^{2} + 2Q \;\;\;\;\; \& \;\;\;\;\; P = 26 - 2Q_{D}
$$

[Find the Monopoly Equilibrium Quantity and Price]{.hi .note .align-center}

[Remember that Monopolists will include the Demand Curve in their Revenue]{.hi .note .align-center}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
[Monopolists Find Quantity from MR = MC]{.hi .align-center}

::: {.fragment .small}
\begin{align*}
    R(Q) &= \color{red}{P} \cdot Q \\
    R(Q) &= \color{red}{(26 - 2Q)} \cdot Q \\
    R(Q) &= 26Q - 2Q^{2}
\end{align*}

[Marginal Revenue]{.hi .align-center .tiny}

\begin{align*}
    MR &= \frac{\partial R(Q)}{\partial Q} \\
    MR &= 26 - 4Q
\end{align*}
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
[Set MR = MC]{.hi .align-center}

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    MR &= MC \\
    26 - 4Q &= 4Q + 2 \\
    8Q &= 24 \\
    Q^{*}_{M} &= 3
\end{align*}
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    P^{*}_{M} &= 26 - 2\color{red}{Q^{*}_{M}} \\
    P^{*}_{M} &= 26 - 2\color{red}{(3)} \\
    P^{*}_{M} &= 20
\end{align*}
:::

:::

::::

---

## Show Profits are Higher in Monopoly Market

$$
    \pi = P \cdot Q - C(Q)
$$

[Find both Market Profits and Compare Them]{.hi .note .align-center}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
[Perfect Competition Profits]{.hi .align-center}
[P = 18 & Q = 4]{.h .align-center .small}

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    \pi_{PC} &= 18 \cdot 4 - 2(4)^{2} - 2(4) \\
    \pi_{PC} &= 72 - 32 - 8 \\
    \pi_{PC} &= 32
\end{align*}
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
[Monopoly Profits]{.hi .align-center}
[P = 20 & Q = 3]{.h .align-center .small}

::: {.fragment}
\begin{align*}
    \pi_{M} &= 20 \cdot 3 - 2(3)^{2} - 2(3) \\
    \pi_{M} &= 60 - 18 - 6 \\
    \pi_{M} &= 36 
\end{align*}
:::

:::

::::

[Which Market Gives Larger Profits?]{.hi .align-center}

::: {.fragment}
$$
    \pi_{PC} \; < \; \pi_{M}
$$
:::
